content: Filipino-Canadian swimmer (born 2001) **Kayla Noelle Sanchez** (born 7 April 2001) is a [swimmer](/wiki/Swimming_(sport)) who has represented the [Philippines](/wiki/Philippines) internationally since 2023. Sanchez initially represented [Canada](/wiki/Canada) until 2022 at the Olympic and World championship level, and is a two-time Olympic medalist in [Tokyo](/wiki/Swimming_at_the_2020_Summer_Olympics). ## Early life Kayla Sanchez was born on 7 April 2001 in [Singapore](/wiki/Singapore), to Filipino parents who were [Overseas Filipino Workers](/wiki/Overseas_Filipino_Worker) (OFWs) in the country. Her father is a native of [Mabalacat](/wiki/Mabalacat), [Pampanga](/wiki/Pampanga) while her mother traces her roots to [Baguio](/wiki/Baguio). After a few years, her family eventually emigrated to Canada. ## Career ### 2017 season Sanchez made her debut in major international competition in 2017, as part of the Canadian team for the [2017 World Junior Swimming Championships](/wiki/2017_FINA_World_Junior_Swimming_Championships) team in [Indianapolis](/wiki/Indianapolis). She won two individual medals, a silver in the 200 m individual medley and bronze in the 100 m freestyle, and was part of a Canadian sweep of the gold medals in the women's relay events, taking gold in the 4x100 m and 4x200 freestyle as well as in the 4x100 medley. In the process the team broke the [junior world record](/wiki/List_of_Junior_world_records_in_swimming) and [championship record](/wiki/FINA_World_Junior_Swimming_Championships#Championships_records). Later that year she also competed at her senior championships, the [2017 World Aquatics Championships](/wiki/2017_World_Aquatics_Championships) in [Budapest](/wiki/Budapest). Sanchez was part of the Canadian team in the [women's 4×100 m freestyle relay](/wiki/Swimming_at_the_2017_World_Aquatics_Championships_%E2%80%93_Women%27s_4_%C3%97_100_metre_freestyle_relay) event, finishing fourth overall. ### 2018 season In September 2017, Sanchez was named to [Canada's](/wiki/Canada_at_the_2018_Commonwealth_Games) [2018 Commonwealth Games](/wiki/2018_Commonwealth_Games) team. Individually, she finished sixth in the [50 m freestyle](/wiki/Swimming_at_the_2018_Commonwealth_Games_%E2%80%93_Women%27s_50_metre_freestyle), seventh in the [100 m freestyle](/wiki/Swimming_at_the_2018_Commonwealth_Games_%E2%80%93_Women%27s_100_metre_freestyle), and ninth in the heats of the [200 m medley](/wiki/Swimming_at_the_2018_Commonwealth_Games_%E2%80%93_Women%27s_200_metre_individual_medley). She won two silver medals as part of the Canadian relay teams in the [4x100 m](/wiki/Swimming_at_the_2018_Commonwealth_Games_%E2%80%93_Women%27s_4_%C3%97_100_metre_freestyle_relay) and [4x200 m](/wiki/Swimming_at_the_2018_Commonwealth_Games_%E2%80%93_Women%27s_4_%C3%97_200_metre_freestyle_relay). ### 2019 season In the Autumn of 2019, Sanchez was member of the inaugural [International Swimming League](/wiki/International_Swimming_League) swimming for the Energy Standard International Swim Club, who won the team title in Las Vegas, Nevada, in December. At the London match in November she won the 200m Freestyle over teammate [Femke Heemskerk](/wiki/Femke_Heemskerk) in a time of 1:52.72. Competing as part of the [Canadian team](/wiki/Canada_at_the_2019_World_Aquatics_Championships) for the [2019 World Aquatics Championships](/wiki/2019_World_Aquatics_Championships) in [Gwangju](/wiki/Gwangju), she won bronze medals in the [4x100 m](/wiki/Swimming_at_the_2019_World_Aquatics_Championships_%E2%80%93_Women%27s_4_%C3%97_100_metre_freestyle_relay) and [4x200 m](/wiki/Swimming_at_the_2019_World_Aquatics_Championships_%E2%80%93_Women%27s_4_%C3%97_200_metre_freestyle_relay) freestyle relays. ### 2020 Summer Olympics In 2021, Sanchez was part of the [Canadian team](/wiki/Canada_at_the_2020_Summer_Olympics) for the [2020 Summer Olympics](/wiki/2020_Summer_Olympics) in [Tokyo](/wiki/Tokyo). She won a silver medal as part of the Canadian team in the [4x100 m freestyle relay](/wiki/Swimming_at_the_2020_Summer_Olympics_%E2%80%93_Women%27s_4_%C3%97_100_metre_freestyle_relay), alongside [Maggie Mac Neil](/wiki/Maggie_Mac_Neil), [Rebecca Smith](/wiki/Rebecca_Smith_(swimmer)), and [Penny Oleksiak](/wiki/Penny_Oleksiak). She also swam the freestyle leg in the heats of the [4x100 m medley relay](/wiki/Swimming_at_the_2020_Summer_Olympics_%E2%80%93_Women%27s_4_%C3%97_100_metre_medley_relay), helping the Canadian team finish the heats in first place, and earned a bronze medal when the finals team finished third (having been replaced in the final by Oleksiak). Sanchez competed individually in the heats of the [100 m freestyle](/wiki/Swimming_at_the_2020_Summer_Olympics_%E2%80%93_Women%27s_100_metre_freestyle), setting a new personal best and qualifying through to the semi-finals, but withdrew to conserve energy for the [4x200 m freestyle relay](/wiki/Swimming_at_the_2020_Summer_Olympics_%E2%80%93_Women%27s_4_%C3%97_100_metre_freestyle_relay), where the Canadian team ultimately finished fourth. ### 2021 season Sanchez announced plans to study political science at the [University of British Columbia](/wiki/University_of_British_Columbia) beginning in January 2022, following the completion of the ISL's third season. As part of her studies she would compete as part of UBC's Thunderbirds swimming team. The season concluded at the [2021 World Swimming Championships](/wiki/2021_FINA_World_Swimming_Championships_(25_m)), where Sanchez won four medals (three gold and one silver) as part of Canadian relay teams. ### 2022 season At the Canadian swimming trials for upcoming championship events, Sanchez was fourth in the 200 m freestyle, before unexpectedly winning the 100 m event, finishing 0.02 ahead of [Penny Oleksiak](/wiki/Penny_Oleksiak). She concluded the event with a decisive win in the 50 m freestyle. Beginning the [2022 World Aquatics Championships](/wiki/2022_World_Aquatics_Championships) in the [4x100 m freestyle relay](/wiki/Swimming_at_the_2022_World_Aquatics_Championships_%E2%80%93_Women%27s_4_%C3%97_100_metre_freestyle_relay), Sanchez was part of Canada's silver medal-winning team, a first for Canadian women at the World Championships. She won her second medal of the championships in the [4×200 m freestyle relay](/wiki/Swimming_at_the_2022_World_Aquatics_Championships_%E2%80%93_Women%27s_4_%C3%97_200_metre_freestyle_relay), where the Canadian team finished third. On the same day, Sanchez placed sixth in the semi-finals of the [100 m freestyle](/wiki/Swimming_at_the_2022_World_Aquatics_Championships_%E2%80%93_Women%27s_100_metre_freestyle), qualifying to her first individual Worlds final. Sanchez qualified to the semi-finals of the [50 m freestyle](/wiki/Swimming_at_the_2022_World_Aquatics_Championships_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_50_metre_freestyle), but scratched from the semi-finals in order to conserve energy for the [4×100 m mixed freestyle relay](/wiki/Swimming_at_the_2022_World_Aquatics_Championships_%E2%80%93_4_%C3%97_100_metre_mixed_freestyle_relay) final in the same session. She recorded a personal best relay split time of 52.52 as part of the Canadian team's silver medal win. Sanchez then competed the freestyle leg for Team Canada in the heats of the [4×100 m medley relay](/wiki/Swimming_at_the_2022_World_Aquatics_Championships_%E2%80%93_Women%27s_4_%C3%97_100_metre_medley_relay), helping the team qualify to the final in fourth position. She was replaced in the final by Oleksiak, but shared in the team's bronze medal win. She, Oleksiak and [Summer McIntosh](/wiki/Summer_McIntosh) jointly set a record at the championships for most medals by a Canadian swimmer at a single edition, with four each. In July 2022, [Philippine Swimming](/wiki/Philippine_Swimming) announced that Sanchez would start representing the Philippines. ### 2023 season [World Aquatics](/wiki/World_Aquatics) would approve Sanchez's sporting nationality change, enabling her to compete for the Philippines from 6 July 2023 onwards. Her competitive debut as a swimmer for the Philippines occurred at the [2022 Asian Games](/wiki/2022_Asian_Games). By late 2023, the [International Olympic Committee](/wiki/International_Olympic_Committee) waived her residency requirement for her nationality change, making her eligible to qualify for the Philippines in the [2024 Summer Olympics](/wiki/2024_Summer_Olympics). ### 2024 Summer Olympics At the games in Paris, Sanchez reached the semi-final stage of the [100m freestyle](/wiki/Swimming_at_the_2024_Summer_Olympics_%E2%80%93_Women%27s_100-metre_freestyle) with a time of 54.21 having set a Philippines national record in the heats with a time of 53.67. ### 2025 season Sanchez swam in the [2025 SEA Games](/wiki/2025_SEA_Games) in Thailand winning three gold medals and five silver medals. She broke three Philippine national records in relay events. ## Personal bests ### Long course (50 m pool) EventTimeMeetLocationDateNotes50 m freestyle**24.68**2021 Canadian Olympic Swimming title: Kayla Sanchez
